results.headline: Review: ‘Live Cargo,’ Human Trafficking, and Other Woes, in Paradise
results.summary_short: This first feature by the director Logan Sandler has great acting, stunning imagery and a vivid Caribbean setting. But its words prove elusive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Live Cargo

results.headline: Review: In ‘Cézanne et Moi,’ Zola and the Artist Are Pals. However ...
results.summary_short: A new film offers an intimate, searching portrait of the turbulent friendship between the writer and the painter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cezanne and I

results.headline: Review: ‘The Discovery’ of an Afterlife, Then the Suicides
results.summary_short: A science-fiction romance starring Robert Redford begins with the premise that proof of what’s next has been found. After that, things turn ugly.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Discovery

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Zookeeper’s Wife,’ the Holocaust Seems Tame
results.summary_short: This true story of a couple who sheltered Jews beneath the Warsaw Zoo has tender moments but its portrayal of the Nazi invasion is too timid and sanitized.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Zookeeper's Wife

results.headline: Review: ‘Karl Marx City’ Revisits the Everyday Terror of Dictatorship
results.summary_short: In this documentary, a filmmaker returns to her hometown in the former East Germany seeking personal and political insight.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Karl Marx City

results.headline: Review: ‘Phillauri,’ an Indian Rom-Com With an Epic Sweep
results.summary_short: Anshai Lal’s Bollywood movie uses a friendly ghost to turn a contemporary comedy into a historical drama that includes a massacre under British rule.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Phillauri

results.headline: Review: In ‘Life,’ Extraterrestrial Fun, Until Someone Gets Hurt
results.summary_short: This movie offers proof of life on another planet, sure, but it is also the occasion for another “Alien”-type deadly game of hide-and-seek.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life

results.headline: Review: ‘I Called Him Morgan,’ a Jazz Tale of Talent and Tragedy
results.summary_short: The director Kasper Collin has created a suave and sensitive documentary about the life and death of the great trumpeter Lee Morgan.

results.headline: Review: ‘American Anarchist’ Is a Frustrating Study in Denial
results.summary_short: A dialogue between the director and the author of “The Anarchist Cookbook” is at the heart of this documentary.

results.headline: Review: In ‘CHIPS,’ Blown-Up Cars Overshadow Buddy Cops
results.summary_short: This unrepentantly lewd comedy, based on the 1977-83 television series of the same name, stars Dax Shepard, who also wrote and directed.

results.headline: Review: ‘Dig Two Graves,’ but the Goodbye Is Only Temporary
results.summary_short: Hunter Adams shows his skill as a filmmaker, delivering a chiller that conjures eeriness and dread without defaulting to abundant gore.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dig Two Graves

results.headline: Review: ‘In Search of Israeli Cuisine’ Isn’t Just About Food
results.summary_short: A documentary raises provocative questions as it follows Michael Solomonov on a tour of Israel’s foodie scene.

results.headline: Review: ‘Saban’s Power Rangers,’ With a Color-Coded Makeover
results.summary_short: The popular 1990s series receives a big-screen reboot, and five new teenage superheroes face off against the latest alien threat.

results.headline: Review: ‘Prevenge,’ Orchestrated by a Fiendish Fetus
results.summary_short: Alice Lowe wrote, directed and stars in this British film about a pregnant serial killer on a darkly comedic odyssey dictated by her malicious fetus.

results.headline: Review: ‘Wilson,’ With Woody Harrelson as a Misanthrope
results.summary_short: A movie, based on Daniel Clowes’s graphic novel, about a man’s well-requited contempt for humanity.

results.headline: Review: ‘I, Olga Hepnarova,’ Carrying Out a Vow of Vengeance
results.summary_short: This Czech film gives a haunting account of the life of the mentally ill young woman who killed eight people in Prague in 1973.

results.headline: Review: ‘A Woman, a Part’ and a Quest to Reconnect
results.summary_short: In Elisabeth Subrin’s feature, a nuanced take on friendship and professional frustration, an actress finds that early relationships can fade.

results.headline: Review: ‘Song to Song,’ Terrence Malick’s Latest Beautiful Puzzle
results.summary_short: This drama about intersecting love lives features themes like betrayal, identity and art. Religion appears, too, in the film, set in Austin, Tex.

results.headline: Review: One Couple’s Promising ‘Taipei Story,’ Slowly Undermined
results.summary_short: The Taiwanese director Edward Yang’s second feature, a portrait of urban alienation from 1985, is getting a theatrical release in the United States.

results.headline: Review: A Return Home Defies a Father’s Wish in ‘P.S. Jerusalem,’
results.summary_short: The filmmaker Danae Elon’s child provides some of the most insightful moments in this documentary chronicling the return to the city of her youth.
